titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 1620: Poems on monastic life

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Ms. Codex 1620: Poems on monastic life are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. notesStmt.note: Printed edition is cataloged separately under the title Speculum perfectionis vene[rabilis] Fr[ater] Henrici Hierp ...

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Preface on holiness in nuns and poems attributed to Denis (Dionysus) Faucher on religious life precede a printed edition of Hendrik Herp's Speculum perfectionis (Venice: Sabio, 1524). The printed material ends with a woodcut of Saint Catherine of Alexandria, and the following manuscript material begins with a hymn to Saint Catherine (f. 9r-10r), followed by additional poems on religious life. Most of the poems by Faucher are a addressed to a nun in the scholasticate (period following novitiate), except for one addressed to Antonius Rorincus (f. 8v).
msContents.textLang: Latin, with the final poem in Italian (f. 16v)

supportDesc.extent: 134 leaves (16 manuscript) : 147 x 96 (109 x 69) mm bound to 149 x 109 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Paper, 16 manuscript leaves; [1-8] (at beginning of volume), [9-16] (at end of volume), modern foliation in pencil, lower right recto.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 17-20 long lines or lines of verse, with the first line of text above the line; frame-ruled in lead.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in a humanistic script, with the last poem written in a humanistic cursive or italic script (f. 16v).

decoDesc.decoNote: Full-page illumination of a nun on the cross above a 4-line verse titled Ad scholasticam (f. 1r) and an illumination of a skull surrounded by bones and flowers (f. 3r), both surrounded by text passages on scrolls; rubrication in red; paragraph marks in red or blue and 1- or 2-line initials in red or blue.
Miniature, Nun on the cross, f. 1v
Miniature, Skull with border of bones and flowers, f. 3r

origin.p: Written in Italy (Zacour-Hirsch) after 1524, the date of the printed edition; probably between 1530 and 1550 (Zacour-Hirsch).

history.provenance: Transferred from Culture Class collection, University of Pennsylvania, 2012.
Possible ownership inscriptions on first printed leaf: F. Franciscus pradice [?]; Ballesdens.
Sold by Lathrop C. Harper (New York), 1962.

keywords.term: Monasticism and religious orders for women--Early works to 1800
